content.text: Learn to read, write, and speak
that is easy to read and write
MiniScript is a modern scripting language designed to be clean, simple, and easy to learn.  It
was designed from the ground up by borrowing only the best ideas from other languages
such as Python, Lua, Basic, and C#.  If you know pretty much any other programming
language, you’ll pick up MiniScript almost immediately.
And if you’ve never written a line of code in your life, don’t panic!  MiniScript is the
friendliest and most fun way to get started.  It’s much easier than you probably expect.
you will usually use it inside some other program, such as a video game.  You should find
another document that describes how to access and use MiniScript within that other
program.  This document only describes the MiniScript language itself, and the intrinsic
functions that are common to most MiniScript applications.
Let’s jump right in with an example, to see what MiniScript code looks like.
Each statement in MiniScript normally occurs on a single line by itself.  Notice that there are
no semicolons, curly braces, or other markers at the end of a line.
However, there is one exception: if you want to join multiple statements on one line, just to
make your code  more compact, you can do this by separating the statements with a
semicolon.  The following code is ugly, but legal.
s = "Spam"; while s.len < 50; s = s + ", spam"; end while
In practice this feature is rarely used, but it's there if you need it.
If you’re used to C-derived languages (such as C, C++, C#, etc.), then you’re used to seeing
curly braces around blocks of code.  MiniScript doesn’t roll that way; code blocks always
) and end with a matching end
You can insert spaces and tabs into your code pretty much wherever you want.  You can’t
break up an identifier or keyword (
of course spaces within quotation marks go into your string exactly as you would expect.  But
between numbers, operators, etc., you can include extra spaces however you like.  The
following two lines are exactly the same, as far as MiniScript is concerned.
To make the structure of code more readable, it’s traditional to indent the lines within a code
block by either a tab or two spaces.  But it’s not required.  MiniScript doesn’t care how or
whether you indent your code, so do whatever works best for you.
Unlike C-derived languages, there are no semicolons or other funny punctuation at the end
of each line to let the computer know that the statement is over.  Instead, the line break
alone is enough to signal that.  But what if you need to enter a statement longer than one
MiniScript will recognize that a statement is incomplete, and continues on the next line, if
the last token (before any comment — see below) is an open parenthesis, square bracket, or
brace; or a comma, or any binary operator (such as
, and so on).  So, for example, you
speech = ["Four score and seven years ago our fathers",
"brought forth on this continent, a new nation, conceived",
"in Liberty, and dedicated to the proposition that all",
That's four lines, but only one statement as far as MiniScript is concerned.  That's because
the first three lines each ends with a comma, which tells MiniScript that more is coming.
Comments are little notes you leave for yourself, or other humans reading your code.  They
are completely ignored by MiniScript.  Comments begin with two slashes, and extend to the
end of a line.  So you can put a comment either on a line by itself, or after a statement.
// How many roads must a man walk down?
Just like indentation, comments are never required… but they’re probably a good idea!
Parentheses in MiniScript have only three uses:
1. Use them to group math operations in the order you want them, just as in algebra.
2. Use them around the arguments in a function call, except when the function call is the
print cos(0)   // parens needed; cannot just say: print cos 0
3. Use them when declaring a function that takes parameters (see the Functions chapter).
Since other languages often require parentheses in lots of other places, it’s worth pointing
used in MiniScript.  First, don’t put parentheses around the
statement (more on these later).  Second, parentheses are not
needed (and should be omitted) when calling a function without any arguments.  For
function that gets the number of seconds since the program began.
It doesn’t need any arguments, so you can invoke it without parentheses.
Finally, as mentioned above, you don't need parentheses around the arguments of a function
that is the very first thing on a statement.  The following example prints ten numbers,
waiting one second each, and then prints a message.  Notice how we’re calling
call, because it has arguments and is used as
part of a larger statement, does need them.
is a word (also called an identifier) associated with a value.  Think of variables as
little boxes that you can store data in.  You create a variable simply by assigning a value to it,
as in many of the examples we’ve already seen.
This line creates a variable called
, if it didn’t exist already, and stores 42 in it.  This
; that is, you can assign any type of data (see
the chapter on Data Types) to any variable.
in scope.  That means that a variable called “x” inside one
function has nothing at all to do with another variable called “x” in another function; each
variable is scoped (restricted) to the current function executing at the time of the
However, MiniScript also supports code outside of any function, as in all the examples we’ve
seen so far.  In this context, local and global variables are the same.  In other words,
outside of a function creates a global variable called
variables may be accessed from any context.
Note that when a context has a local variable of the same name as a global, an identifier will
always resolve to the local variable first.  Similarly, a simple assignment statement within a
function will always create a local variable, rather than a global one.  In cases where you
really need to access the global variable instead, there is a
access.  (See the Intrinsic Functions chapter for more detail on
print x           // prints the global x (40)
x = 2             // creates a local ‘x’ with a value of 2
print x           // prints the local x (2)
print globals.x   // prints the global x again (40)
print x           // still the local value (2)
print globals.x   // prints the new global value (42)
x = 40   // creates a global ‘x’ with a value of 40
Overuse of global variables can sometimes lead to tricky bugs, so it’s best to use them
sparingly and rely on local variables as much as possible.  MiniScript is designed so that this
good practice is what happens naturally.
As a convenient shorthand, the math operators (
.  This does a math operation with a variable, and assigns the result back to
that variable.  For example, the math-assignment form:
means exactly the same thing as:
The previous rules about local and global variables still apply.  So, to update a global variable
in math-assignment form, you would write something like this.
This works not only for numbers, but for any data type where the operator used is defined.
Uppercase and lowercase matters in MiniScript.  The
, or any other variation.  The same applies to any
variables, functions, or classes you define.
While how you use case in your own identifiers is up to you, a common convention is to
capitalize classes (e.g. Shape), but use lowercase for variables.  Thus the following would be a
shape = new Shape   // create a Shape object called shape
While we're on the subject of conventions, in most cases you should avoid starting any global
variables or function names with an underscore.  Identifiers starting with an underscore are
often used by the host environment for special “under the hood” code, and name collisions
is how you make code execute multiple times, or execute only under certain
conditions.  Without it, your scripts would be limited to starting at the first line, executing
each line exactly once in order, and ending after the last line.
MiniScript includes one kind of branching (conditional) structure, and two kinds of loops.
statement to specify some condition under which the following statements
should be executed.  The basic syntax is:
When the condition is not true, MiniScript will jump directly to the
print "I have found the Ultimate Answer!"
The whole set of lines, from
Sometimes you want to do something else when the specified condition is not true.  You can
print "I have found the Ultimate Answer!"
Finally, you can check for additional conditions by adding
slightly more practical example that converts a number to words.
print "You have a lot of apples!"
In this case, the first condition that matches will execute its block of lines.  If none of the
Note that for all these forms, the
on its own line.  However, there is also a "short form"
statement that allows you to write
on a single line, provided you have only a single statement for the
block, and a single statement for the
if x >= 0 then print "positive" else print "negative"
is not used with a short-form
way to put more than one statement into the
block.  If you need more than
one statement, then use the standard multi-line form.
statement loops over a block of code zero or more times.  The syntax is:
The whole block is referred to as a
.  On each iteration through the loop, the variable
is assigned one value from the specified list.  You'll learn more about lists in the Data Types
chapter, but for now, it's enough to know that you can easily create a list of numbers using
This example counts from 10 down to 1, and then blasts off.
function in the Intrinsic Functions chapter for more options on that.
Instead of a list, you can also iterate over a text string.  In this case the loop variable will be
assigned each character of the string in order.
Finally, it is also possible to iterate over maps.  Again, maps will be explained in the Data
Types chapter, but just keep in mind that when you use a
statement with a map, then on
each iteration through the loop, your loop variable is a little mini-map containing
This prints out each of the key-value pairs in the map.
The other way to loop over code in MiniScript is with a
This executes the contained code as long as
is true.  More specifically, it first
evaluates the condition, and if it's not true, it jumps directly to
then it executes the lines within the loop, and then jumps back up to the
The process repeats forever, or until the condition becomes false.
This is illustrated by the very first example in this manual, repeated here.
This code builds a string (s) by adding more spam to it, as long as the string length is less
than 50.  Once it is no longer less than 50, the loop exits, and the result is printed.
There are two additional keywords that let you bail out of a while or for loop early.  First, the
statement jumps directly out of the loop, to the next line past the
, which is equivalent), it is an infinite loop —
statement in the body of the loop.  As soon as that
executes, we jump directly out of the loop.  It works for
loops in exactly the same way.
In the case of nested loops,
breaks out of only the innermost loop.
statement skips the rest of the body of the loop, and proceeds with the next
iteration.  This is often used for "bail-out" cases in a large loop, where under certain
conditions you want to skip an iteration and just go on with the next one.
This will print out the numbers 1 through 100,
for 42, which is skipped.  Note that if
in this example, the loop would print the numbers
We have talked about evaluating conditions as true or false, without explaining what that
really means.  Usually you don't need to worry about it, but here are the details anyway.
Boolean (true/false) values in MiniScript are represented as numbers.  When conditions are
statements, a value of 0 (zero) is considered false; any other
value is considered true.  In fact the built-in keywords
equivalent to the numbers 1 and 0 respectively.
When you use comparison operators such as
(less than or equal), these compare their operands and evaluate to either 1 (if true) or
See the Numbers section of the Data Types chapter for more boolean operations you can
Finally, in a context that demands a truth value — that is, in an
— other data types will be considered false if they are
empty, and true if they are not empty.  So an empty string, list, or map is equivalent to 0
(zero), and any non-empty string, list or map is equivalent to 1 in these contexts.  The special
things you can store and manipulate
Variables in MiniScript are dynamically typed; you can store any type of data in any variable.
But what types of data are there?  In MiniScript, there are four primary data types:
.  There are a couple of other more obscure types, such as function
and null.  Everything else, including classes and objects, is actually a special case of a map.
All numeric values in MiniScript are stored in standard full-precision format (also known as
“doubles” in C-derived languages).  Numbers are also used to represent true (1) and false (0).
Numeric literals are written as ordinary numbers, e.g.
You can use the following operators on numbers (where
are not functions; they are operators, and go between (or in the
, before) their operands just like all the others.
numeric sum of a and b
numeric difference of a and b
remainder after dividing a by b
a raised to the power of b
a * b, clamped to the range [0,1]
a + b - a*b, clamped to the range [0,1]
1 if a is not equal to b, else 0
1 if a is greater than b, else 0
1 if a is greater than or equal to b, else 0
1 if a is less than b, else 0
1 if a is less than or equal to b, else 0
You can check whether a variable contains a number with the
Text values in MiniScript are stored as strings of Unicode characters.  String literals in the
code are enclosed by double quotes (
).  Be sure to use ordinary straight quotes, not the
fancy curly quotes some word processors insist on making.
If your string literal needs to include quotation marks, you can do this by typing the
s = "If you do not help us, we shall say ""Ni"" to you."
Strings may be concatenated with the
operator, and if you try to add a number and a string
together, the number will be automatically converted to a string and then concatenated.
Strings may also be replicated (repeated) or cut down to a fraction of their former selves, by
multiplying or dividing them by a number.
The full set of string operators is shown below;
string formed by concatenating t to s
if s ends in t, returns s with t removed; otherwise just returns s
s repeated n times (including some fractional amount of s)
(all indexes are 0-based; negative indexes count from end)
substring of s up to but not including character n
substring of s from character n to the end
substring of s from character n up to but not including character m
1 if s is not equal to t, else 0
1 if s is greater than (collates after) t, else 0
1 if s is greater than or equal to t, else 0
1 if s is less than (collates before) t, else 0
1 if s is less than or equal to t, else 0
The table above does not include
, but these operators work perfectly well
on strings through boolean coercion (see "The Nature of Truth" in the previous chapter).  In
any boolean context, s is considered true if it contains any characters, and false if it is the
Also not listed is behavior of the
operator with strings.  There is an intrinsic type called
The slice operators deserve a bit of explanation.  The basic syntax is
substring of s starting at character n, and going up to (but not including) character m, where
we number characters starting from 0.  But this basic syntax is extended with a handful of
1. You may specify just a single index, leaving out the colon, to get a single character.  Thus
2. You may use a negative index, and it will count from the end.  So
is the next-to-last, etc.  This works for any of the slice indexes.
3. You may omit the first index from the two-index form, and it will default to 0.  This is a
handy way to get the first n characters of a string.  So
returns all but the last three characters of s.
4. You may omit the last index from the two-index form, and it will continue to the end of
skips the first three characters and returns the rest of the string.
The way these indexes work results in a lot of very handy properties.  For example,
for any value of n from 0 through
; in other words, there is a very
natural syntax for splitting a string into two parts, which is a fairly common thing to do.

string and assign it to an existing variable.  The following example
shows one correct and one incorrect way to change “spin” into “spun”.
The third basic data type in MiniScript is the
.  This is an ordered collection of elements,
accessible by index starting with zero.  Each element of a list may be any type, including
You define a list by using square brackets around the elements, which should be separated
The code above creates a list with four elements and assigns it to x.  But again, list elements
don't have to be numbers; they can also be strings, lists, or maps.  Here's another example.
Working with a list is very much like working with a string.  You can concatenate two lists
, replicate or cut a list with
, and access elements or sublists using the same
slice syntax.  Here are the operators valid on lists, where
The slice operators work exactly the same way as with strings.  So
skips the first three elements and returns the rest of the list, and so forth.
However, there is one important difference: lists are
or using one of the list methods like
how many different variables are referring to that list, they will all see the change.  The
a = [1, 2, 3]   // creates a list and assigns to a
b = a           // assigns that SAME list to b
a[-1] = 5       // changes the last element of our list to 5
Because a and b both refer to the same list, any changes (
) made to that list can be
If you want to be sure you have a fresh copy of a list, rather than a shared reference, a
to make a slice that includes the entire list.  This copies the
elements into a new list.  Compare the following example to the previous one.
list formed by concatenating q to p
p repeated n times (including some fractional amount of p)
(all indexes are 0-based; negative indexes count from end)
sublist of p up to but not including element n
sublist of p from element n to the end
sublist of p from element n up to but not including element m
a = [1, 2, 3]   // creates a list and assigns to a
b = a[:]        // assigns a COPY of that list to b
a[-1] = 5       // changes the last element of our first list to 5
print b         // prints: [1, 2, 3]  (our copy hasn't changed)
The final basic data type in MiniScript is the
.  A map is a set of key-value pairs, where
each unique key maps to some value.  In some programming environments, this same
Create a map with curly braces around a comma-separated list of key-value pairs.  Specify
each pair by separating the key and value with a colon, as shown here.
The map created here contains three key-value pairs, each mapping a number to a string
(which happens to be the English word for that number in this example).
Map keys should be numbers or strings, and must be unique; if you reuse a key, the previous
value is replaced.  (Technically a key may be a list or another map as well, but in this case, it's
important that you do not mutate the key, or the behavior is undefined.)  Values may be any
type, including lists or maps.  Order within a map is not preserved;
Maps support only a handful of operators (
There are two ways to get and set members of a map.  The first is to use the square-brackets
index operator, just as with strings or lists, except that in the case of a map, the key can be a
string as well as a number (or even a list or another map, if you are very careful).
The second way is using the
.  This works only in the special case where the key is
a string that is a valid identifier: it begins with a letter, and contains only letters, numbers,
and underscores.  In this case you can write the key after a dot rather than enclosing it in
square brackets and quotation marks — the key essentially becomes an identifier in the
language.  The following is functionally equivalent to the previous example.
map formed by assigning d[k] = v for every k,v pair in e
value associated with key k in d
value associated with (string) k in d
This dot indexer is mostly syntactic sugar that makes accessing elements of a map easier to
read and write.  But there are some subtle differences in cases where the map represents a
class or object, as described in the next chapter.
Finally, like the other basic types, there is an intrinsic class that represents maps —
will return true for any map (including any class or object, as
you'll see in the next section).
operator was mentioned several times above.  This is how you can check, at
runtime, what sort of data you have.  In many cases you won't care, thanks to MiniScripts
automatic type conversion.  But sometimes you do.
Suppose for example you want to make a method that prints its argument surrounded by
parentheses... but if the caller passes in a list, then you want to join the elements of that list
with commas.  You could accomplish that with
if x isa list then x = x.join(", ")
your own classes (which you'll learn about next, I promise).  You can add new methods to
them, and then invoke those methods using dot syntax on ordinary numbers, strings, lists,
and maps.  (The only limitation is that you can't use dot syntax with a numeric literal.)  If
this sounds like Greek to you, don't worry — it's an advanced feature, and one most users will
The table below shows all the operators in the MiniScript language, along with their
precedence.  Operands in an expression chain will always be grouped by higher-precedence
operator is higher precedence than the
logical OR: true if either operand is true
logical AND: true if both operands are true
logical negation: true if its operand is false, and vice versa
equality comparison: true if operands are equal
inequality comparison: true if operands are not equal
power: A raised to the power of B
the building blocks of sophisticated software
is essentially a sub-program that does some particular task.  We've already seen
some of the functions built into MiniScript, such as
There are many more of those, which will be documented in the next chapter.  But the real
power of a programming language comes from defining your own functions.
Beyond that, as a program grows in size and complexity, it becomes useful to start organizing
.  A class is basically a collection of functions and data, where
share the same functions but may have unique data.
A function in MiniScript is a special data type, at the same level as numbers, strings, lists,
and maps.  You can define a function with the
keyword, assign it to a variable,
and then invoke it via that variable, just like the built-in functions.  Here's an example.
This declares a function that triples any value given to it, and assigns that function to a
.  The triple function is then invoked, with and without an argument.
The syntax for declaring a function is:
is a comma-separated list of zero or more parameters, each of the form
.  When a function is invoked, arguments will be matched up to
the functions by position.  If fewer arguments are given than parameters are defined, the
remaining parameters are given their default values — and if no default value was defined for
that parameter, then it is set to
Note that the parentheses after the
keyword are required only if there are
parameters.  In the case of a function with no parameters, the parentheses are not required
(and by standard convention, should be omitted).
It's important to understand that a function is itself a bit of data.  It's just that, whenever
looking up the value of a variable, MiniScript checks for this special function data type; and if
found, it invokes that function, rather than returning the function itself.
Usually that is exactly what is wanted, as in the example above.  But occasionally you may
want to copy the function reference, rather than invoking the function.  You can do this by
Here we've again declared a function and stored it in a variable called
that function into another variable called
.  At this point we can invoke
, and both do exactly the same thing.  Had we
on the assignment, MiniScript would have instead evaluated the function
refers to, and assigned the result (3) to
Here's a more realistic example.  We'll define a function called
given function to each element of a list.  Then we can invoke this on a list with any function,
to refer to the function we want to apply.
result = lst[:]                  // make a copy of the list
result[i] = func(result[i])    // apply func to each element
To summarize, you invoke a function by simply using any identifier that refers to it.  You
avoid this invocation, and refer instead to the function itself, by putting
MiniScript allows you to define functions within functions.  This is an advanced feature that
most users may never need, but it can come in handy on occasion, especially in conjunction
with something like the “apply” method above.  Just as with any other local value, you might
want to avoid cluttering the global namespace just for a function that you only use in one
place.  Here’s a simple example that assumes we have the
So inside the function referred to by the (global variable)
function, and assign it to the (local variable)
.  Then we pass that function in as the second
function (or more pedantically, to the function referred to by the
When you have a nested function like this, it can access the local variables of the function
that contains it.  Just as with global variables, it can do this without any prefix (as long as
there isn’t some local variable with the same name getting in the way).  But to assign to a
variable of the outer function, you must use the special identifier
refers to the outer function, and
function both reads that value, and updates it using
code carefully to see if you can figure out what it prints... and then try it and see if you were
Again, this nested-function business is an advanced feature which beginners can safely forget
about.  But for advanced users, it is a language feature worth understanding.
That is, there is fundamentally no difference in MiniScript between a class and an object; the
difference, when it exists at all, lives solely in the intent of the programmer.
A class or object is a map with a special
entry that points to the parent (prototype).
This is an implementation detail you rarely need to worry about, because it is handled
1. When you create a map using the special
2. When you look up an identifier in a map, MiniScript will walk the
for a map containing that identifier.  The value returned is the first value found.
chain, and returns true if any map in that
chain matches the right-hand operand.  In other words,
These simple rules provide almost everything needed for object-oriented programming.  A
series of "classes" may be defined as maps containing functions and default data, which are
inherited or overridden as needed.  An "object" is just another map, inherited from some
class, which normally contains only custom data.
Let's illustrate with an example.  We'll define a class called Shape, with a subclass called
A base class is just an ordinary map; in this case, we added a
signifying that “sides” is a bit of data we expect every Shape to have.  Then we created a
,  and assigned this to Square.  In Square, we overrode the
Now let’s create an instance of our Square class, again by using
Notice how we’re using the traditional OOP terminology of “class” and “instance” for
convenience, but in reality, there are just three maps — Shape is the prototype of Square, and
Square is the prototype of x.  The
member of each map points to the prototype,
Now let’s add a function to the Shape class, which should work for any shape subclass or
This example illustrates one additional rule important to object-oriented programming:
• When a function is invoked via dot indexing, it receives a special
to the object on which it was invoked.
So in the example above, we invoked the
function is invoked, a special local variable called
map in the search chain.  This allows class functions to access object data.
There is just one more bit of special support for object-oriented programming, and that is
keyword.  This is another built-in variable (similar to
invoke a method via dot syntax, but when you call another method via
method on the base class, while keeping
bound to the same value as in the current

it.  Continuing the previous example, suppose we want to define a subclass of Square that
always has 42 more degrees than nonmagical shapes would have:

, so it invokes that, with a
There are maps that represent each of the basic data types:
.  These contain the built-in methods for those types.  By adding new methods to one of
these maps, you can add new methods usable with dot syntax on values of that type.
For example, while there are built-in string methods .upper and .lower to convert a string to
upper- or lower-case, there isn’t a method to capitalize a string — that is, convert only the
first letter to uppercase.  But you could add such a method in your program as follows.
The function itself is fairly simple: if our string (
) is less than 2 characters long, just
uppercase the whole thing; otherwise uppercase the first letter, and append the rest.  But
because we have assigned this function to
, that is, added it to the
map, we can call it with dot syntax on any string.
There is one limitation to this trick.  Numbers are a little different from other data types;
MiniScript does not support dot syntax on numeric literals.  So
works fine (assuming you have defined an appropriate
built-in functions you can rely on
MiniScript comes with a standard set of built-in (or
globals (i.e., referred to by variables in the global space).  Others (particularly functions
intended for use with strings, lists, and maps) are normally invoked via dot syntax after an
In fact, though, all intrinsic functions that use dot syntax are written in such a way that they
be invoked as global functions.  So, for example, you can get the length of a string
, but you can also do the same thing as
The following tables list the standard intrinsic functions, divided by data type on which they
operate.  Keep in mind that MiniScript is intended to be embedded in some host
environment, such as a game or application.  The host will normally add additional intrinsic
functions particular to that environment.  Please consult the documentation or help
materials for your host environment for information on these extra functions.
MiniScript includes a selection of trigonometric functions, which all work in radians (rather
than degrees), and other math functions, as well as random numbers and conversion of
arctangent of y/x, in radians (returns correct quadrant if optional x parameter is used)
treats x and y as integers, and returns bitwise "and" of a and b
treats x and y as integers, and returns bitwise "or" of a and b
treats x and y as integers, and returns bitwise "exclusive or" of a and b
next whole number equal to our greater than x
returns Unicode character with code point i (see string
next whole number less than or equal to x
are designed to be invoked on strings using dot syntax, but
can also be invoked as globals with the string passed in as the first parameter.  Note that
strings are immutable; all string functions return a
logarithm (with the given base) of x, i.e., the value y such that base^y == x
returns a list containing values from x through y, in increments of step; step == null is
treated as a step of 1 if y > x, or -1 otherwise
x rounded to d decimal places
if seed=null, returns random number in the range [0,1);
if seed != null, seeds the random number generator with the given integer value

are designed to be invoked on lists using dot syntax, but can
also be invoked as globals with the list passed in as the first parameter.  Lists are mutable;
functions modify the list in place.  To use a list
like a stack, add items with
.  To use a list like a queue, add
splits the string into a list by the given delimiter, with at most maxCount entries (if
maxCount is unspecified, then splits into a list of any size)
1 if i is in the range 0 to self.len-1; otherwise 0

inserts value into self at the given index (in place)
builds a string by joining elements by the given delimiter
removes and returns the last element of self (like a stack)
removes and returns the first element of self (like a queue)
appends the given value to the end of self; often used with pop or pull
randomly rearranges the elements of self (in place)
sorts list in place, optionally by value of the given key (e.g. in a list of maps)

(if maxCount not specified, then all occurrences are replaced)
Functions on maps are very similar to functions on lists. Maps (like lists) are mutable; the
methods modify the map in place.  You can treat a map
, which inserts 1 (true) for the value of the given key, and
returns a key and removes it (and its value) from the map.  Keep in mind that the order of
keys in a map is undefined.
1 if x is a key contained in self; 0 otherwise
list containing all keys of self, in arbitrary order
first key in self that maps to x, or null if none; optionally begins the search after the
length (number of key-value pairs) of self
remove and return an arbitrary key from self
removes the key-value pair where key=x from self (in place)
replaces (in place) up to maxCount occurrences of value oldval in the map with
newval (if maxCount not specified, then all occurrences are replaced)
total of all numeric values in self
list containing all values of self, in arbitrary order
The following functions relate to the operation of MiniScript itself, or interact with the host
environment.  The latter (print, time, and wait) are only quasi-standard, in that support for
them depends on the host application, and so they may not function in some environments.
reference to the global variable map
a map containing all the global intrinsic functions
reference to the local variable map for the current call frame
convert x to a string and print to some text output stream, optionally followed by delim;
if delim is not specified, the output is followed by a line break in most environments
returns 1 if a and b refer to the same instance (not just equal values)
returns the current call stack, as a list of strings
number of seconds since program execution began
wait x seconds before proceeding with the next MiniScript instruction
wait for next invocation of main engine loop (e.g., next frame in a game)
small programs that do interesting things
While we’ve given short examples of MiniScript code throughout this manual, this chapter
presents several longer, more interesting examples.  Many of the tasks illustrated are taken
from RosettaCode, an online database of programming challenges with solutions in many
languages.  You can go there to compare the MiniScript solution to any other language; you
may be amazed how much more readable MiniScript is than the alternatives.
is a standard introductory-level programming challenge .  The task is simple: print
for multiples of three, print “Fizz” instead of the number;
for multiples of five, print “Buzz” instead of the number, and for any number that’s a
There are clearly many ways to tackle this; here’s one.
Instead of just hard-coding a loop from 1 to 100, we’ve made a function that can FizzBuzz up
to any number.  Within that function, the only clever bit is line 3, which takes advantage of a
couple of MiniScript features.  First, comparisons (such as
zero”) evaluate to 1 when true, or 0 when false.  Second, you can multiply a string by a
number to repeat it that many times.  This means that if you multiply a string by a condition,
you get either the original string (if the condition is true) or the empty string (if it is false).
That lets us easily generate “Fizz”, “Buzz”, and “FizzBuzz” depending on what our loop
counter is divisible by.  Line 4 simply fills in the number if we don’t get one of those strings.
(Quiz: can you rewrite this line to use the same multiply-by-condition trick as line 3?)
Here’s another RosettaCode task : select certain elements from an Array into a new Array in
a generic way.  To demonstrate, select all even numbers from an Array.
filter = function(seq, f)  // filter seq to where f is true
This is a pretty straightforward conversion of the task description into MiniScript code.  Our
function takes a list and a function, and builds a new list by appending each element
where the function, applied to that element, is true.
function that returns true only when its argument mod 2
is zero (i.e., the argument is evenly divisible by 2).  Then we pass
even elements of a given list.
Here’s a function that finds the biggest number that can divide evenly into two given
numbers .  Middle schoolers everywhere will soon be out of work.
The algorithm here, known as the “Euclidian algorithm for finding the GCD,” is clever.  The
MiniScript does not have a standard intrinsic for finding the maximum element of a list.  But
you can easily add it yourself, using this code.
if item > max then max = item
Pretty simple stuff.  Line 2 checks to make sure the sneaky user hasn’t given us an empty list;
if they have, we return null, as there is no sensible max in that case.  Otherwise, we just
suppose it’s the first element, and then loop over each element in the list, keeping the
variable assigned to on line 1 is in the global variable space, while the
assigned on lines 3 and 5 (and then returned on line 7) is local to a function.  These
happen to have the same name, but have nothing to do with each other.  As a matter of style,
it might have been better to name the local variable
like a good opportunity to demonstrate how local and global variables are separate, even if
MiniScript has intrinsics to convert a string to all upper- or lower-case letters.  But what if
you want to capitalize just the first letter of each word, and lowercase the rest?
print titlecase("SO LONG and thanks for all the fish")
We just iterate over the string, capitalizing each letter that is either the very first character in
the string, or is preceded by a space, and lower-casing the rest.
The previous version of Titlecase works fine, but is somewhat suboptimal, because it grows a
string by adding to it character by character.  This recopies the earlier characters in the string
many times.  The following code shows a better way.
print titlecase("SO LONG and thanks for all the fish")
Here we start by splitting the string into characters (by using the empty string as the
delimiter to split on).  Then we iterate over the string, updating each character in our list,
and join them back together at the end.
